flags.title: User-Contributed Project
flags.text: This project guide is not managed by MAKE staff.

guide.introduction:
I find it difficult to clean the inside of gourds that are tall or have a small opening. There are gourd tools on the market made for this particular job, but they are certainly not cheap. I found that I can make my own with just a few simple parts.

These tools will come in handy for my other gourd projects here on Make.
guide.introduction_rendered:
I find it difficult to clean the inside of gourds that are tall or have a small opening. There are gourd tools on the market made for this particular job, but they are certainly not cheap. I found that I can make my own with just a few simple parts.

These tools will come in handy for my other gourd projects here on Make.

Relevant parts
  • #8 x 3/8" hex sheet metal screws.
  • Steel pipe
  • Wooden ball
  • Wire mesh and a piece of wire or heavy duty string
Tools
  • Drill bit, sized to screws
  • Drill bit, sized to solid steel pipe.
  • Drill gun
  • Epoxy

parts.notes: You can go with a smaller size
Choose a diameter that will fit your drill. I cut mine to 16" in length.
I used 1.5" diameter, you can go with something bigger - but no smaller.

parts.text: Wire mesh and a piece of wire or heavy duty string
parts.notes: These two parts are for the sanding tool.

lines.text: After cleaning and sanding the shell of the gourd I painted pine trees around the top half. I first made leafless trees and then with a liner brush I painted on the needles.
lines.text_raw: After cleaning and sanding the shell of the gourd I painted pine trees around the top half. I first made leafless trees and then with a liner brush I painted on the needles.

lines.text: TIP: Liner = Thin Paint. Whenever you are painting with acrylic paint, and you want a thin line, (such as pine needles) you need to thin the paint to an ink consistency.
lines.text_raw: '''TIP:''' Liner = Thin Paint. Whenever you are painting with acrylic paint, and you want a thin line, (such as pine needles) you need to thin the paint to an ink consistency.

lines.text: After making the pine needles I filled in the branches with a bit more green. I applied this with a  minimal amount of paint on a stencil brush and pounced it on the tree branches.
lines.text_raw: After making the pine needles I filled in the branches with a bit more green. I applied this with a  minimal amount of paint on a stencil brush and pounced it on the tree branches.

lines.text: Using a stylus and graphite paper I transferred my drawings of various deer onto the gourd without any of the details. Just a simple trace over the main lines. (BTW, always make sure that you can easily erase the graphite. Some brands are easier to erase than others.)
lines.text_raw: Using a stylus and graphite paper I transferred my drawings of various deer onto the gourd without any of the details. Just a simple trace over the main lines. (BTW, always make sure that you can easily erase the graphite. Some brands are easier to erase than others.)

lines.text: You can see the other half of the cropped photo showing that I keep all the drawings handy by taping them to my shelf at eye level. This helps me when it comes time to woodburn the deer. I'll be able to see all the details that I need to woodburn.
lines.text_raw: You can see the other half of the cropped photo showing that I keep all the drawings handy by taping them to my shelf at eye level. This helps me when it comes time to woodburn the deer. I'll be able to see all the details that I need to woodburn.

lines.text: I use the Everglades Patriot 1000 Wood Burning System for most of my woodburning although I still sometimes go back to the hobby woodburner with interchangeable tips. My hobby woodburner is the Walnut Hollow brand and has been a very reliable one for me compared to the others I've used. I'd check that one out first if you're new to woodburning.
lines.text_raw: I use the Everglades Patriot 1000 Wood Burning System for most of my woodburning although I still sometimes go back to the hobby woodburner with interchangeable tips. My hobby woodburner is the Walnut Hollow brand and has been a very reliable one for me compared to the others I've used. I'd check that one out first if you're new to woodburning.

lines.text: The fixed tip pen I am using in the first photo is the "Writing Tip." At just the right temp I can use this pen like a real pen. If using a variable temperature woodburner first experiment on a scrap piece of gourd to find the right temp for the job at hand.
lines.text_raw: The fixed tip pen I am using in the first photo is the "Writing Tip." At just the right temp I can use this pen like a real pen. If using a variable temperature woodburner first experiment on a scrap piece of gourd to find the right temp for the job at hand.

lines.text: For light shading I scrape the gourd back and forth pretty quickly with the tip to leave slight marks in the gourd. This is called directional shading. Remember to follow the contours of the object you are woodburning when doing directional shading.
lines.text_raw: For light shading I scrape the gourd back and forth pretty quickly with the tip to leave slight marks in the gourd. This is called directional shading. Remember to follow the contours of the object you are woodburning when doing directional shading.

lines.text: Other methods of shading I like to use are dots (the closer the dots the darker the shading) and gradient shading, which I do with the flat side of a tip, darkening the gourd in varying degrees without leaving a pattern.
lines.text_raw: Other methods of shading I like to use are dots (the closer the dots the darker the shading) and gradient shading, which I do with the flat side of a tip, darkening the gourd in varying degrees without leaving a pattern.

lines.text: To cut deep grooves in the gourd like I did for the hoof prints in the second photo I used the knife tip.
lines.text_raw: To cut deep grooves in the gourd like I did for the hoof prints in the second photo I used the knife tip.

lines.text: After woodburning the deer I used brown shoe polish to darken the surrounding area to make the deer stand out.
lines.text_raw: After woodburning the deer I used brown shoe polish to darken the surrounding area to make the deer stand out.

lines.text: I use microbrushes (very similar to a super tiny pipe cleaner with a plastic handle) to get into the very tiny places.
lines.text_raw: I use microbrushes (very similar to a super tiny pipe cleaner with a plastic handle) to get into the very tiny places.

lines.text: I use cotton swabs to do the larger areas, but when I have really large places to cover with shoe polish I use a paper towel. Yes, it can get messy, but that's part of the fun. :)
lines.text_raw: I use cotton swabs to do the larger areas, but when I have really large places to cover with shoe polish I use a paper towel. Yes, it can get messy, but that's part of the fun. :)

lines.text: I carved the hoof prints out with my rotary tool using a carbide ball bur. I also carved three deep lines on the gourd with an inverted carbide cone bur. My rotary tool is a variable speed Dremel with a flex-shaft attachment.
lines.text_raw: I carved the hoof prints out with my rotary tool using a carbide ball bur. I also carved three deep lines on the gourd with an inverted carbide cone bur. My rotary tool is a variable speed Dremel with a flex-shaft attachment.

lines.text: And as a finishing touch I dyed the bottom of the gourd a deep chestnut color with Memories Ink water-based dye. I used a heat tool to speed up the drying process.
lines.text_raw: And as a finishing touch I dyed the bottom of the gourd a deep chestnut color with Memories Ink water-based dye. I used a heat tool to speed up the drying process.

lines.text: Your finished gourd must be varnished or sealed after all your dyes and inks have been cured. This may take up to a week. Polyurethane is my go-to sealer, but acrylic spray will work, too.
lines.text_raw: Your finished gourd must be varnished or sealed after all your dyes and inks have been cured. This may take up to a week. Polyurethane is my go-to sealer, but acrylic spray will work, too.

lines.text: Coming from Michigan as I do, I found my inspiration in white pines and white-tailed deer. Deer grow like trees around here! Coincidentally, both are Michigan official state symbols.
lines.text_raw: Coming from Michigan as I do, I found my inspiration in white pines and white-tailed deer. Deer grow like trees around here! Coincidentally, both are Michigan official state symbols.

lines.text: Start by drilling a single hole in the wooden ball. Screw in hex screws - as many as you can fit. Attach the studded wooden ball to the metal pipe with epoxy.
lines.text_raw: Start by drilling a single hole in the wooden ball. Screw in hex screws - as many as you can fit. Attach the studded wooden ball to the metal pipe with epoxy.

lines.text: An alternative to the hex screws is a wire mesh wrapped around the wooden ball. I used both a copper pot scrubber (see third photo) as well as a piece of an old window screen. The window screen I find to be more abrasive; while I mainly use the copper mesh for light work like smoothing the interior after all large debris has been removed.
lines.text_raw: An alternative to the hex screws is a wire mesh wrapped around the wooden ball. I used both a copper pot scrubber (see third photo) as well as a piece of an old window screen. The window screen I find to be more abrasive; while I mainly use the copper mesh for light work like smoothing the interior after all large debris has been removed.

lines.text: Use these tools as drill attachments to clean the inside of tall gourds you can't put your hand inside.
lines.text_raw: Use these tools as drill attachments to clean the inside of tall gourds you can't put your hand inside.

guide.summary: Make tools to clean the interior of gourds quicker and easier.
guide.title: DIY Cleaning Tools for Gourd Art

tools.notes: Used for pilot holes for the screws.

tools.text: Drill bit, sized to solid steel pipe.
